content: Eligibility for health benefits under CHIP is available to different groups through various federal authorities and mechanisms, including children, pregnant women, parents, and childless adults. Title XXI defines a targeted low-income child as someone under 19 without health insurance and not eligible for Medicaid before March 31, 1997. States can set the income level for these children up to 200% of the federal poverty level. CHIPRA allows states to expand eligibility for children up to 19 years old to any level they choose. For states seeking CMS approval to expand eligibility, federal CHIP payments are reduced for higher-income children. The regular Medicaid FMAP will be used for CHIP enrollees with family income exceeding 300% of poverty. States can expand eligibility for children up to 19 years old under CHIPRA. Federal CHIP payments are reduced for higher-income children, using the regular Medicaid FMAP for CHIP enrollees with family income over 300% of poverty. States may assist qualifying children by covering them under Medicaid or creating a separate CHIP program. When states provide coverage to low-income children through separate CHIP programs, Title XXI rules typically apply, with federal CHIP funds covering program costs. Title XXI does not establish individual entitlement to benefits but entitles states with approved CHIP plans to federal allotments based on a distribution formula. Title XXI does not establish individual entitlement to benefits for low-income children covered under separate CHIP programs. States can cover these children by expanding Medicaid programs through new eligibility groups authorized in Title XXI. States can expand coverage for low-income children under Medicaid programs by either creating a new optional eligibility group authorized in Title XXI or by adjusting the financial rules for existing Medicaid eligibility categories. Many states opt for the latter option to cover targeted low-income children under existing Medicaid pathways, reducing administrative burden. Additionally, states may choose to provide coverage for these children through a separate CHIP program. States can reduce administrative burden by creating a separate CHIP program to provide coverage for targeted low-income children. Title XXI allows states to determine eligibility based on factors such as geography, age, income, resources, residency, disability status, access to other health insurance, and duration of CHIP.
